title: What kind of a singer are you? - Quora

response.answer_text: Ooooooh, loaded question!!  i have taken 8 years of voice and currently am in a classic rock band. I am somewhat ashamed that at the band’s average age i don't like saying that we were doing this stuff when it was top 40! But I have done professional theater for years, lead in a pre-Broadway musical but my favorite role was Fanny Brice in Funny Girl! My preference is the classic rock genre, but my song writing style goes from country to rock. Our group was selected by Tampa Bay Times music critic (who I think hated every band) but there was readership of 3 million, as one of the 14 album of the years and said we were the Bays answer to Fleetwood Mac. A European critic gave the album 4 stars, which was more than he gave to Kelly Clarkson and Maroon 5! Not too shabby for our first CD of predominantly originals and produced for a total of 5k. Big band was fun for a few years and many of the guys played with Glen Miller, Jimmy and Tommy Dorsey, Stan Kenton, Buddy Rich working with Frank Sinatra, Doris Day, Helen O'Connell. It was wonderful to have their experiences with these singers. If I couldn't get a handle on a song, the guys were right there with advice like, “well, when we recorded this song with Doris Day, this is how she handled that section.”. I think that is really where I learned about phrasing and breathing into the song, and the working knowledge those guys had was invaluable! !! What did I learn from all these different influences? To me every song is a one act play, with an expose of conflict, working on the situation of the character in the song, and at the end, determining the resolution of the song and the emotional response of the audience to the song story. Guess I have rambled on enough. I hope this answers your question!

I started singing & parroting famous singers as a small child(age 2 actually, couldn’t say the words correctly sometimes, but could repeat the melody). Was always in music class & choir, 1st Chair….Won Many talent contests in elementary ,Jr/Senior High, & as an adult. Started classical training in voice a few months before I turned 15, & continued for 12years, even saw my teacher back in 2009 for a refresher( & she was 90!).Won Regional & State UIL competitions, sophomore, junior & senior Yrs in solo voice, 3 Gold Medals in HS. Was in professional Musical Theatre by 16. Offered 3 music scholarships in voice. Sang lead & bkng vocals + percussions w/some basic keyboard, in my first cover band by 19, touring US, Mexico & Europe. Sang anything from Cheryl Lynn to Fleetwood Mac, to Loretta Lynn to Streisand. I’ve been doing Streisands’ voice since I was 9, & Stevie’s voice since 19. I’m a Lyric Soprano, classically trained,with a solid 5 octave range(age has dropped it a few notes from 5 1/2 octaves).I became a Streisand Tribute Artist in the ‘90s, after I was approached in a Vegas club by a producer, who remarked on my resemblance to Barbara & asked if I could sing like her, I said “funny you should ask”, & he asked me to prove it, so I sang right then & there, standing at the bar counter at this club, where I Caused a stir, & he gave me his card said call me, I did, & I’ve worked all over the globe as Barbra, from Vegas, to Puerto Rico, Asia, So. America, & across Europe. I enjoy all kinds of music, but doing Barbra’s is the most fulfilling for me. I enjoy the technical aspects of her music, the lyric etc. There are quite a few videos on youtube. Some I’ve posted, some by others. You can look me up via search Cindy Harrelson as Barbra Streisand, if you’re curious. Cheers!

Well, I ’m not a professional singer. Don’t have the instrument down well enough to sing perfectly in tune…I started too late in life, when I started writing songs with lyrics when I was about 35 or so. I never sang before that, but I had to sing my own songs - I couldn’t expect someone else to it for me. In a studio, with headphones, I can do OK, but singing live with a loud band is tough, ’cause you can’t hear yourself well enough over the drums. I don’t have a “pretty” voice either. Sometimes it resembles the sound a sick man makes when he’s puking in the toilet or maybe a man in distress or raging against his plight. But I’m also self critical.

Good question. I am a professional, versatile singer. It's hard for me to give one genre as I worked in almost all of them. It's also hard for me to give a range as I have been hired to sing in a crystal clear soprano voice as well as a raspy whisky alto. I've worked in pop, electronica, hard rock, country, hip hop, classical and musical theatre. So I feel like the versatility is what kept me working. I have sang on children's records replicating a 13 year old only to sing a blues gig the same night. Mostly, I'm a singer who is grateful for the gift.

How do I tell what kind of singer that I am? I started singing in 2017 but i never set out wanting to sing! i'm actually just a drummer not a singer! i love music myself, and alway wanted to play in a band, but nobody seemed interested in having a bash at it. So over the past five years or so I started trying to learn the harmonica, also having a go at self teaching some guitar, and now i am singing! I just went on smule app and gave it a go i never thought that would be a good singer by any means i just needed to hear my voice when recorded to a song! So after singing my very first song i just posted it.thats when i got all positive feedback and followers that like my sound. So back to the question, i just have go at singing any song thats infront of me, when singing on smule i dont practice singing songs any invitations to collabs, even songs I never heard before, I sing it and post it after just one take, smile app is great its amazing how easy it is to make recording of a song thats sounds professional in so little time and effort! So again back to the question! I think the listeners should deside as to what kind of singer I am. Thanks, jaykerry2 smule, singer!!.

I am what is called a “power ballad” singer, meaning I love singing songs by others or written by myself that are slower (love songs, sad songs) to showcase my strong/powerful singing ability. Examples of this type are: Hero, by Mariah Carey, Whitney Houston’s version of I Will Always Love You, or Sam Smith’s song Stay With Me and many others. I usually sing within the female vocal range, or high/falsetto male voice. I’ve been singing since the age of 3, have “perfect relative pitch”, and have no formal music training. Thanks for the great question!

To be honest - I am a poor singer with a narrow range and inconsistent pitching. For many, many years I played in various bands and did not sing. Then I joined a band where I was required to contribute backing vocals - I found that I kinda enjoyed it. Now I perform in a duo and sing 50% lead, I also perform solo playing acoustic guitar and singing. I still consider myself a pretty awful singer with a limited range however I work hard at it and am gradually improving. Occasionally I carefully analyse phrase by phrase what 'real' singers do (eg Van Morrison) to try to understand and emulate their inflections, phrasing and other subtleties - it may not come naturally to me but that doesn't mean I'm going to give up. And recently I've even had some unsolicited compliments about my singing voice - it hasn't changed my opinion but encourages me to continue working at it. I envy real singers ..

Oh my my. I so badly want to answer this question. I still remember that beautiful morning. It was chest day and I don’t know why I have a habit of shouting the lyrics of the song whenever I life heavy (that last 3–4 reps). Unfortunately, the song playing in my earphones at that time was I’m a barbie girl. (It somehow started playing automatically on youtube, don’t judge me lmao). Now imaging a 170 pound guy, In sleeveless shirt, benching 190 pounds and in the last couple of sets shouts “arhh I’m a barbie girl mm ”. Hell it was embarrassing. damn. There were a lot of people there, including a couple of girls, one of which I sort of like. They started laughing weirdly as if they have seen dwyane johnson in pink skirt. What I did was just picked up my stuff and silently slid off the gym (like a cool breeze in the night)

I don’t have enough musical training know, to be honest. Choir directors have put me with the altos, with the sopranos, and one put me in the position of that soprano who’s higher than the others. Of the three categories, the middle soprano position is least comfortable for me. I’ve had professional musicians (including singers) compliment my singing, though, even actively encouraging me to pursue it, so I have some ability. I’ve been told my voice is “clear”, whatever that means. [shrug]

If I had to classify, I would say its an alternative/folk style, due to mostly being all over the place, but excelling in softer calmer music. I am self taught, so I sing a range of rock, alt rock, celtic, folk, and other things that are easy on the voice. Now that doesn't mean I have a weak voice by any means, as I have been able to sing songs that other singers struggle with power wise, its just I lack control that is taught better than picked up.

I am classically trained. I took voice lessons for a couple of years starting when I was a senior in high school. I took some later, when I was in my early 30s for a few years, and again for four years in my late 50s. I can sing in several languages. I have sung solos at many weddings and funerals, and many times in church. I have sung big band music with a concert band that was a total blast. I have sung in community choirs and am in one now. I love singing our national anthem at baseball games, banquets, and the Shrine Circus I am a fairly versatile singer.

I would have to say that I’m a singer of various genres. I can sing rock, pop, r&b, soul, country pop, teen pop, electropop, synth pop, dance pop, Minneapolis sound, and reggae. On a skill level, I’d say I’m not professional, but I can sing very, very well. I can basically reach the highest notes like Michael Jackson, Prince, Steven Tyler, T-Pain, Jason Derulo, and Trey Songz.

One that merely sings for fun. I have zero voice training, but I would like to get it one day because apparently a few people think I can sing pretty well. I personally think I'm just good at mimicry. A trained singer would be able to tell that I don't sing from my diaphragm, which is something I want to master soon.

Your question ia rather to general. Do you want to know vocal range? Style? What type of music? I will answer all of them. My style is a jazz bari tenor E2 - A#4 plus falsetto. My style is classic jazz in the vein of Frank Sinatra, Tony Bennett and Bobby Darin. Type of music classic jazz, country and folk standards. Hope this answers your question.
well i hope i am good i am a un- Black Metal Singer and which is hard for people to do because you have to act like you sigh while using the high note which is hard for some people to do
Bathroom singer.

A good one, I hope. I was recently in Portugal for a music festival and after running some repertoire with another participant (he was the accompanist), I asked ‘So what did you think of the songs?’ He thought for a while, then replied ‘I liked that you had flawless intonation’. I was a little taken aback; I'd expected something like ‘Good choice of repertoire’ or something similar. But yeah, you know, a singer who can't stay on pitch is like a drummer who can't keep time. Thanks for the A2A.
See the videos of me and my students singing and see for yourself. Robert Lunte & Student Performances
A bad one, though I’m not bad in the bass register. I have two others and can’t hold a note in either of them.
I’m a tenor with a low raspy, hoarsed type voice. The clarity is there and it’s a full tone.
Hopefully an opera star tenor.
I want to be a singer like rock .
